abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            unsatisfactory, sustainability unlikely, and institutional
            development impacts modest. Lessons learned follow. Although
            conventional wisdom spells political stability as a
            necessary ingredient for the successful implementation of a
            reform program, the appraisal team factored political risk
            into the operation, and attempted to minimize the
            probability of policy reversals, by front loading initial
            reform measures, as the prior actions for credit
            effectiveness. Irrespective of the fact that
            multiple-tranche operations are ill-suited for countries
            under political instability, in this case, the risk of
            "wastage" was minimized by linking the
            disbursements of subsequent tranches, to the payment of
            domestic arrears, which to a certain extent, the design
            proved appropriate, with a result - though not the desired
            ex ante - consistent with what would have happened if the
            model of multiple-tranche operations, would have been
            retained. As for capacity building, the idea to
            "budget" technical assistance (TA), rather than
            rely on a stand-alone project, has been positive: it
            fostered ownership of reforms, and positively impacted
            capacity building. But for this model to deliver expected
            outcomes, a constant dialogue should be maintained on
            implementation of the TA program. Further issues arise
            regarding capacity building, and the sustainability of
            assistance: varying degrees of success question the
            modalities, while deeper "institutionalization" of
            the skills acquired is still necessary. Finally,
            institutional assessments should not just focus on
            strengths, and weaknesses of individual agencies, but on the
            communication channels, and interagency cooperation as well,
            to ensure consistency between macroeconomic, and sectoral
            dimensions of the policy dialogue.
